projectDesc.p: Text digitized and encoded for use in the Forager Folklore Database. The FFDB offers a basis for a systematic study of narrative universals, the evolutionary origin of storytelling, and (comparative) folklore studies.

samplingDecl.p: The narrative was selected for being a genuine piece of oral literature recorded directly, or mediated by an interpreter, from a narrator who either lived or grew up as a member of a culture whose subsistence at the time of recording was, or until recently had been, depending primarily on hunting, gathering, and/or fishing. Care was taken to ensure the quality of the recording and the relative absence of external cultural influences.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the p prefix are pointers to person elements in the personography.xml file.
URIs using the q prefix are Wikidata Q identifiers and refer to the respective entries on Wikidata.
Private URIs using the g prefix are pointers to the respective lemmas in the FFDB collection of glossaries.

editorialDecl.p: Footnotes are generally retained, but no effort has been made to link the narratives mentioned in comparative notes with corresponding records within the FFDB.
Page numbers have been retained, but page beginnings, pb, occurring within a word have been moved either before or after the word (or nominal phrase) on a case to case basis, without general rule.

normalization.p: Omissions as well as supplementations by the original editor are set in brackets. In all other cases, parentheses in the original are retained.
Latin passages in the original (usually to mask language and themes deemed indecent) are rendered in English.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation has been removed. All other hyphenation has been retained.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained. No effort was made to mark up passages in quotation marks as, for example, q, quote, said, cit, or soCalled.

p.note: The free translation given here is a compromise between a relatively close translation that reflects the rapid-paced delivery of the original and one that is understandable. As noted above, the first three sentences do not appear in the recording. In addition, the two sea creatures are not identified or described until late in the narrative, the first being a shark and the second something quite extraordinary. While this may reflect either the fact that the story is well-known to the Seris or contributes to the fast pace of the action, it makes it less understandable to an outsider. I have added some bracketed material to help the reader.

body.p: CöquimaxpThe name Cöquimaxp ('who is light pink', variation of cöquihmaxp) probably indicates something about the man's skin complexion, although this is not mentioned in the story. People have typically had nicknames of this type; see Marlett (2008a). The phonetics may suggest that the name is simplified to Cöimaxp (or an orthographical variation of this) as appears in previous publications; this would not be surprising. The expression for light pink is believed to be etymologically related to the root for 'white': √ooxp. - Since many people died in this incident, it is not clear why the story begins and ends with only the mention of the man named Cöquimaxp. was one of the San Esteban Island people.This sentence gives two alternative ways to refer to the inhabitants of San Esteban Island. The second is the more prosaic of the two, while the first one uses a name (Hast) that is primarily used in special contexts. For more information about the Seri groups that lived in the area, including San Esteban Island, see E. Moser (2017). There were four subgroups on the island, one of which was known as the Cofteecöl Iifa group, referring to the peninsula that is mentioned further below. The name Cofteecöl itself has a disputed etymology. One of these, often cited in earlier work, understands it as reference to large (-eecöl) chuckwallas (coof). Another option, told to me unsolicited a number of years ago by Priscila Moreno Díaz, a descendant of one of the last residents of San Esteban Island, is that it refers to coft (plural of cof 'San Juanico tree'). This species of tree is not found on the island today, a fact that has caused some people to question the authenticity of the explanation. He was an adult, but he was small. When he sat behind a water jug, only the crown of his hat could be seenThe itni of a hat is its crown. The word appears here in a modified form, with an infix, to add a rhetorical effect of an imprecise nature but apparently relating to the fact that 'just' the crown could be seen above the large water pot. The water pots in question were large clay pots made with great skill, today found only in museums. For more information, see Bowen & E. Moser (1968)..Sentences 1-3 are not in the original recording; they were presumably added by Roberto Herrera Marcos and Edward W. Moser as they prepared the text to be used in the community. These sentences give some crucial background information that Jesús Morales did not include in this telling. Well, the people were first on San Esteban Island, but they left there ...This sentence is interrupted by an explanation of why the people left San Esteban Island. The sentence after the next could be viewed as its continuation. They had been eating chuckwallas and sea lions,The place of chuckwallas and sea lions as food resources for some groups of Seri people has been well documented; see Felger & M. Moser (1985:49, 53). but they had depleted the sea lions that were there, [while other sea lions] fled [the area]In this sentence we are led to understand that the sea lion population had not been completely wiped out, but that some of the animals had gone elsewhere, with the result that there was a food shortage for the people. ... [The people] went toward that other mountain [a place on San Lorenzo Island].This sentence picks up from the next to last one. The peak [of that place on San Lorenzo Island] was oriented with a point [out into the sea]; it is almost like an island, and the place resembles an estuary.Bowen (2000) provides more information about the geographical features discussed here relating to the location on the west side of the southern part of San Lorenzo Island. The San Esteban people called it Xtaasi Hapee - "Gift Estuary"As Xavier Moreno explained, the word Hapee here, while very similar to the form hapé ('what is heard') from quii 'to hear', is a form of the irregular verb quiye 'to give food to'. As he was told by a relative, the same name Xtaasi Hapee occurs for another body of water in the Seri area and indicates that food is always found there. [And so the people] were there [for some time], they were eating those animals, including sea lions [and chuckwallas]. They were there ...Again, Morales begins a sentence and then interrupts it, this time with an explanation about the chuckwallas. The chuckwallas there are bigger than normal. They are like the size of toddlers but they are black, extremely black. Their form is like that of a normal chuckwalla, and they are called 'black chuckwallas'.There are three kinds of chuckwallas in the area: Sauromalus obesus (northern chuckwalla, called both coof and ziix hast iizx ano coom), Sauromalus varius (San Esteban Island chuckwalla or piebald chuckwalla, called coof), and Sauromalus hispidus (spiny chuckwalla, called coof coopol); the latter has a darker skin than the others (Felger & M. Moser 1985, Bowen 2000, Moser & Marlett 2010). [And so the people] were there with food to eat. And as another year was about to begin,This is taken to mean that the people had been there for a year. someone said: "Maybe we should return to San Esteban Island. A year has gone by. The century plantFrom Felger & M. Moser (1985:222): "This highly variable subspecies [of century plant] is endemic to San Esteban Island, and is the only agave occurring on that island. [...] Unlike all other agaves in the Seri region, edible plants of this species could be found throughout the year. However, they are most flavorful during the latter part of January. [...] The hearts, cooked and mixed with sea turtle fat, were said to have a coconut-like flavor." stalks have emerged.When the century plants were prepared for roasting in underground pits, the developing inflorescence was cut out and discarded (Felger & M. Moser 1985:222-227). The inflorescence is mentioned here to indicate that this would be the right time to harvest the century plants. No matter which century plant we might choose to eat would be sweet. So maybe we should return." [And so they started on their trip back.]

They were going in seven reed boats.Reed boats were used until the early part of the twentieth century; one of the last ones was obtained by Edward H. Davis and is part of the Smithsonian Institution collection. More information about these craft may be found in McGee (1898:215-221) and Felger & M. Moser (1985:131-133), where they are also referred to as balsas. Reed boats were also used by indigenous groups in Baja California; see MacFarlan & Henrickson (2010:59). They were crossing the sea. They had killed lots of sea lions and were transporting them.This fact surely was one of the reasons why a shark would be attracted to them. There was one family in each reed boat. While
they were coming, they were on this side of San Esteban Island, and the bottom of the sea was roaring, and [someone] said: "A sea creature went there! Paddle! Paddle!" The one called "Blue Shirt" was in the lead [boat], and the creatureThe creature is later identified as a large white shark. arrived to [the people on the reed boats] and quickly grabbed them one after another and ate them, all except "Blue Shirt" [and his group]; it tried to chase him, but ["Blue Shirt"] was fast. He was as fast as if he were in a motorboat, and he made his reed boat jump over a big sea current on his way. [He was fast] because he had spiritual power, and not because of his own strength. [The creature] chasing him, ...This sentence is another one that is incomplete. The action picks up after the next two sentences.

Cofteecöl Point is a long peninsula on San Esteban Island.This notable spit on the southwestern side of San Esteban Island is listed as El Cascajal in Spanish-language sources (Bowen 2000:18). It extends toward San Lorenzo Island. They went to the south side of it, and went ashore, but [the shark] was there out in front and did not leave. The people made a fire, [the shark] smelled the smoke, and did not leave; it just stayed there. Two nights passed, and then in the morning, ...This is another incomplete sentence; the next two sentences are an explanatory insertion, after which the action picks up again. In that direction [south] there is a place called Hastojiicöla - "Tall Mountains". [Another creature], a large sea animal, was getting closer, making noise in its throat as it came. It came to the surface, and it seemed to growl as it came. Then [the shark], which was lying on the surface of the sea, took notice of [the oncoming creature], and gradually turned around to face it. At the same time, [the other creature] was coming into view. While [the other creature] was coming, [the shark] turned around to face it straight on. While the other one was coming, [the shark] faced it straight on and went out to meet it. [The other creature] arrived, and the two met and were almost standing up in the water [as they fought], and the sea water flowed over the land as they did. During that time, [Blue Shirt and his group] pulled their reed boat up farther on land as they were there on San Esteban Island watching. And that other creature killed the white shark called 'wrinkled skin.' The other creature was something like a huge chuckwalla or like a spiny-tailed iguana. It had come and killed [the shark]. After it had killed it, it returned to where it came from, going up and down in the water as it went. That's how it went away, going in the same direction that it came from.

Then, [Blue Shirt and his group] launched their reed boat and took it around [the point] to where a lot of people were living; they were their relatives. The people near the place called Pajii were a family, and they were living near a large arroyo there. [Blue Shirt and his group] arrived and told them the sad news: "The balsas, and all the people, they have all died. Even the children, they have ..."Xavier Moreno pointed out that this sentence is incomplete out of respect for the deceased.
That's how it was that Cöquimaxp, died, little person that he was. He was a grown man, but he was little. That's how he died. And that's the end of the story.
